first_story_block:
Ha ha ha! I can’t help but laugh as I peer down from the mouth of my lair. Another foolish knight stands at the foot of my mountain. Another foolish knight who believes he can defeat me, the great and mighty Knarr'ator. I don’t know why you humans bother trying.

Let me tell you right now; you don't stand a chance against me. I doubt you can even make it up here. The mountain’s walls are sheer. There’ll be no walking up here. You should seriously just consider abandoning your fruitless quest and go home.

Or you could try to climb up. I’d at least get a kick out of it.

action_results.result:
Ah ha ha ha ha ha! That’s right, human! Walk away! Walk away like the coward you are! See you later, alligator! After a while, crocodile! Au revoir, dinosaure!

You retreat back to your little village and enjoy a boring, boring humanly life. One which doesn’t involve your being eaten by a dragon. I guess you could call that a “plus”, but in the grand scheme of things, does that really matter? Your life remains insignificant either way.

You grab a firm hold of the rocky face and manage to pull yourself about three feet off the ground. Omicron good job. You’ve only got, maybe, 700 feet to go? 900? I’m not entirely sure, myself.

Anyway, you’ve got a bit of a choice to make—a “fork in your path”, if you will. Do you continue straight, or do you steer a little to the side? The rock on your right looks to be loose, but then again, the one straight ahead… Hmm… I guess it’s a good thing I’m not making this decision!

You choose the rock to your left and climb to it with ease. Well, aren’t you the skilled mountaineer all of the sudden? You actually manage to make it about halfway up. What’s that, about 500 feet? In any event, that’s pretty high up. I wouldn’t look down if I were you.

So, my fledgling cragsman, in which direction will you further your ascent?

You reach for the leftward rock, but the moment you get a firm grasp upon it, it breaks from the mountainside and you are sent plummeting to the hard ground below, landing with an ever-so-satisfying thud. Funny. In just five seconds you’ve gone from knight to carcass... It’s almost a shame. Almost.

I’ll have to remember to scrape you off the ground later.

Have you looked down yet? Pretty long drop, eh? Eh?

You grab the rock ahead of you and hoist yourself up further. How lucky of you to have made it up this high. You’ve almost reached the top. You’re so, so close. But you’re not there yet. One wrong move and you’re done. Dangerous stuff. Have you looked down yet?

So, which direction will you pick now, I wonder?

You reach for the leftward rock, but the moment you get a firm grasp upon it, it breaks from the mountainside and you are sent plummeting to the hard ground below, landing with an ever-so-satisfying thunk. Funny. In a mere seven seconds you’ve gone from knight to carcass... And you were so close, too. It’s almost a shame. Almost.

I’ll have to remember to scrape you off the ground later.

You reach for the forward rock, but the moment you get a firm grasp upon it, it breaks from the mountainside and you are sent plummeting to the hard ground below, landing with an ever-so-satisfying thunk. Funny. In a mere seven seconds you’ve gone from knight to carcass... And you were so close, too. It’s almost a shame. Almost.

I’ll have to remember to scrape you off the ground later.

Favoring the dextral route, you, despite all odds, haul yourself up to the mouth of my cave.

Wow. You actually made it to the top. I’m impr—well, no. Not “impressed”. A bit surprised, is all. But none of that matters. By now, I’ve already retreated to my chamber, which is situated deep within my lair. Tread carefully, knight, for each route is dark and full of terrors. I’m curious as to which one you’ll dare to choose.

Ooh, are you sure you can handle such a terrifying place as the Hall of Skulls? The walls are adorned with the bones of my victims. That’s right. Spooky, scary skeletons. All around you. Grinning. Staring. Plotting. Decaying.

You take a few steps forward and quickly realize you’re not alone. In front of you stand the reanimated bones of a swordsman. For fleshless bones, they give off a pretty foul stench. The swordsman swings its blade in a horizontal motion, aiming straight for your neck.

You duck, narrowly avoiding the attack. The skeleton, recovering from its attack, is now in a position for you to retaliate. You ready your sword and lash at the thing, but in which direction do you swing?

Your horizontal swing of the sword keeps it mostly intact, but it is enough to separate its legs from its body. The skeleton, now about two-thirds of its original height, is however still able to lurch its saber at you. The blade penetrates your meager armor and pierces your heart. Your life is over within seconds.

How heartless of that guy, huh? ...Too soon?

You swing the sword vertically. As the blade strikes at the shoulder, the skeleton quite literally shatters; fragments of rib, sternum, and other assorted bones fly in all directions. I’m not entirely sure how you managed that, but a win’s a win, I guess. Cleaning the mess up, though, is something I’m not looking forward to.

Okay, so you made it through the Hall of Skulls. Big whoop. It’s not like it’s gonna get any easier. You continue to venture deeper into my lair, until something stops you in your tracks.

Careless as you are, you seem to have ended up bumping into something. Something firm… and warm. You look up to see that standing before you is none other than wyvern. His scales are a pale golden, he’s a bit on the chubby side, and—wait a minute… Just who the heck is this guy? I didn’t invite him! I don’t even know him! He shouldn’t be here!

He tilts his head a bit as he examines you. “Hello,” he says with a bit of a grin. “My name’s Vernon.”

Ugh. A wyvern named “Vernon”? Just… just, whatever you do, don’t pay any attention to what he has to say. Ignore him.

“You’re a knight, right?” he continues. “Are you here to slay Knarr'ator?”

Ha ha ha! You idiot! Hadn’t it crossed your mind that he might be one of my loyal subjects, and now, given what you just told him, he’s going to kill you? I told you to ignore him. You only have yourself to blame.

“Wonderful!” he says as his grin widens. “Please, allow me to assist you. If you promise me I can have some of his treasure, I’ll tell you his weakness.”

…

…What. Okay, c’mon now; don’t listen to him. He’s lying. He… he just wants you dead so he can sneak in and steal my treasure. I totally don’t have any weaknesses. Seriously. None. None at all.

You actually have the gall to take him up on his offer, and the two of you shake on your stupid little agreement. I can’t believe you’re really going to trust him. Really pathetic, if you ask me.

“Alright,” he says, still wearing that smug snicker on his face. “Knarr'ator may think he’s awesome. Maybe he thinks he’s invincible. But he’s got perhaps the dumbest weakness I’ve ever heard of. That weakness is... double negatives.”

Sheesh... Are you hearing this guy? So I don’t like double negatives. As if a strong dislike of an improper use of grammar can be considered a “weakness”. Who the heck does he think he is?

With that useless bit of information now imparted upon you, you continue on your quest, stopping when you come to yet another fork in the path. Go on; choose your next destination.

action_results.result: The Maze of Twisty Little Passages? Really? Well, who am I to stop you? Have fun getting lost. You make your way into the maze and are greeted with three paths. Which path do you take?
You take the left path and find yourself again with three paths to take. You’re in a Maze of Twisty Little Passages. Where to now?

Taking the path straight ahead, you finally manage to escape from that crazy maze. Maddening, that thing is. I don’t even know why I have it. Well, anyway, you’d better get on with your stupid little quest, don’t you think?

A massive dragon looms over you as you enter the final chamber. As in me. It’s my chamber. I’m the looming dragon.

“Oh, you’ve made it to my chamber already?” I inquire. “Are you that eager to get yourself killed? Well, come on then. Show me what you’ve got.”

I’ll let you make the first move. Go ahead. Don’t disappoint me.

You make a break for it.

“Really?” I sigh. “After all this, you’re just gonna run away? There’s no way I’ll stand for this.”

Despite my size, I’m actually quite fast and I effortlessly catch you between my claws. I dangle you above the ground, swinging you back and forth as I contemplate you. Making up my mind, I snap my jaws shut upon the upper half of your body, severing you at the waist. You’re delicious.

For whatever reason, you fling your sword at me. It misses. Completely.

I chuckle. “Good job, knight. You’ve disarmed yourself.”

Well, since you wasted your turn being stupid, I guess it’s my turn now. I inhale deeply, preparing to unleash a wave of deadly dragonfire upon you.

You do a decent job of avoiding the flames. But obviously you can’t dodge them completely, so you end up a little singed. But just a little. It’s hardly noticeable.

I’m done with fire breathing for now. Instead, I swing my sharp claws in your direction.

You make no effort to avoid my attack, focusing solely on the retrieval of your weapon. My claws connect, tearing into your neck and leaving long gashes down your chest. You bleed out in a matter of moments.
You dodge my claws. Good for you. I decide to swing my tail at you.

You make no effort to avoid my attack, focusing solely on the retrieval of your weapon. My tail strikes you hard, sending you flying back a good 20 feet. While you struggle to get up, I charge at you, prepared to sink my teeth into your armor.

I’m running towards you. You’re heading for your sword. But I make a misstep; I trip over your blade and I’m sent hurtling towards the ground. I fall flat on my face. Humiliating, to say the least. I look up to see that you now have your sword pointing at me.

“Now, now,” I say, your sword held firmly at my throat. “Let’s not get hasty. Nobody needs to be killed today. Especially not the one narrating this story. Why don’t you put that sword down and think about this?”

You’re not buying it. You came here with the intent of slaying a dragon, and there’s no changing your mind. Despite my every protest, you callously take your blade and force it deep into my chest.

“Ack…”

“Urk…”

“You bastard… My story… is ruined…”

The second you move your sword away from my throat, I knock it from your hands. Ah ha ha ha ha! You fool! You complete and utter fool! Do you know how close you were? How close you were to victory? But now, I win, and you lose, and there’s nothing you can do abou—

Just then, Vernon the wyvern peers in. …You know what? Forget about narrating. I need to go exterminate that little pest.

I’ll be right back. Probably.
You avoid getting bitten. Simply amazing. I swing my claws at you.
You dodge my tail. Wow. I bare my teeth and get ready to bite you.
You make no effort to avoid my attack, focusing solely on the retrieval of your weapon. My teeth sink into your flesh and I tear your head from your neck. I swallow it in one gulp. Mmm… Delicious.

Despite the inferno raining upon you, you head straight for the sword, and straight to your doom. I envelop you in flames. They swallow you whole; they melt your armor to your flesh and burn you alive. Within moments, you’re nothing but cinders. Crispy, smoldering cinders.

You recklessly charge forward, presumably in the hopes of striking me with your sword. I dodge it fairly easily.

Nice try. Now it’s my turn. I inhale deeply, preparing to unleash a wave of deadly dragonfire upon you.

Despite the inferno raining upon you, offense is all you can think about, and that proves to be your downfall. I envelop you in flames. They swallow you whole; they melt your armor to your flesh and burn you alive. Within moments, you’re nothing but cinders. Crispy, smoldering cinders.

You swing your blade at my while I’m arguing with you. I get it. You’re trying to distract me. It’s not gonna work.

Oh, ho ho! The Riddle Room! You step inside and find that it is almost entirely empty. The only noticeable feature is an arch-like crevasse in the wall. Hint: it’s a hidden door.

“If a tree… falls in a forest, and no one is around to hear it, does it make a sound?”

“Correct!” the voice sounds. “A falling tree is going to make a sound regardless of whether it will be heard or not. You… May… PASS!”

The rocky wall slides upward, granting you passage further into my lair. So I may have… uh… lied about the difficulty just a tad. Like, just a teeny tiny bit. But whatever. Just continue on your stupid quest.

I’d say I told you so, but… Well, no. I did tell you so. This is in no way my fault.

You reach out to grab the rightmost rock. A strange feeling comes over you as your hand swipes past the bare mountainside. Once again you lose your footing, and once again you fall to the ground.

Oh gods, that’s rich. Did you forget there was nothing to hold on to? Or did you actually want to fall? I’m kinda questioning your intentions now.

You waste a good ten minutes looking for another path that may lead up the mountain to my lair. You find nothing. Absolutely, positively nothing of any use whatsoever. But really, what did you expect? A set of stairs? I’m a dragon; I can just fly up here, so why would I need those?

Unless you’re planning on sprouting some wings in the near future, you’re gonna have to climb.
